Dr. John Coleman Bennett, President and Reinhold
Niebuhr. Professor of Social Ethics at Union Theological
Seminary of New York, will be a guest lecturer in the
Sherwood Room of Levering Hall, next Monday, at 4:15.
Dr. Bennett's lecture, one of the Jeffery Memorial series,
is entitled "Christian Faith in a Period of Cold War."
Dr. Bennett received his education at the Exeter Academy, Williams College (A.B.), Oxford University (A.B.), and
Union Theological Seminary (B.D.), from which he graduated
summa cum laude. He has received five honorary doctorates,
from institutions such as Williams, Oberlin, and P&M. He has
written a number of publications, is editor of Nuclear Weapons and the Conflict of Conscience, and is co-chairman of
the editorial board of Christianity and Crisis.

Pigskin Hop
The annual Pigskin Hop will be held this year on Saturday evening, November 21, at the Oregon Ridge Ski Lodge.
Sponsored by the H Club, the dance is being held to obtain
funds for the purchasing of blankets and other tokens as
awards of recognition for men who participate on Hopkins
teams three years in a row.
The lodge was chosen as the site of the dance because
of the attractive setting and intimate atmosphere it will
afford. It is located on Beaverdam Road, just off the York
Road expressway.
Music will be provided by a local band, the Lafayettes,
and set-ups will be available but not provided. Sport jacket
and tie is the dress for the occasion.
This year, only two hundred tickets will be sold, in order
to preserve the cordiality of the setting. Tickets sell for five
dollars apiece, and may be obtained in the basement of
Levering Hall.

Class Day
In the traditional Fall anti-apathy campaign, Class Day
ranks high at the Hop. Friday, Nov. 20, at 1 p.m. classes
will be suspended to facilitate the annual struggle between
the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior classes.
Students are expected to compete vigorously for their
classes in such events as ping pong, touch football, and
assorted novelty races. For those who feel they can best aid
their class effort through mental endeavor, there will be
bridge, chess, and possibly debate competitions. In any event
healthy class struggle is a sure counter to the lethargic
mildew mid-terms impose upon us all.

Discussion and action on the fraternity discrimination
issue which has been raging for six weeks was formally

Steve Reynolds, president of Phi Gam, the fraternity

racial discrimination. He said it was simply a matter of
misinterpretation.
Matt Liang countered with the question, "How can
Orthodox Jews and Negroes be misinterpreted?"
Reynolds then held up a letter from Phi Gam national
headquarters which stated that there was "no language in
the charter of Phi Gamma Delta that supported discrimination on religious or racial grounds." When asked to produce a copy of the charter Reynolds explained that the
charter was a secret document known only to the fraternity
brothers and could not be shown for inspection.
The Council, out of respect for the integrity of Phi Gam
and its national organization, decided not to press the matter
any further and thus brought to a close six weeks of debate.

Library
In a brief but impressive ceremony last Saturday
morning President Eisenhower formally dedicated the
new Hopkins research library.
Among the dignitaries present were Eli Frank, Jr.,
and Albert Hutzler, both trustees of the university.
During the ceremony Dr. Eisenhower presented a
complete collection of Ex Libris, a publication of the
Hopkins library, to Mr. Hutzler in appreciation of his
long interest and support of the library.
The Johns Hopkins Glee Club, accompanied by an
organ, sang the school ode and song.
Librarian John H. Berthel concluded the proceedings
by formally opening the new building to the public.
Guided tours through the structure's interior started
at the ceremony's conclusion and continued through
the afternoon.
On Sunday a reception was given in the library
for the donors.
Today and Saturday
The Association of Research Librarians is centering
its attention on the new Homewood Library as some
65 librarians from 20 states and Canada examine the
facilities of the $4.7 million structure.
Coming from such schools as Toronto, the University of Texas, Columbia, Cornell, and the University
of California, the librarians will be interested in the
physical structure of the building and the application
of computer techniques in library operations.
Many of the visiting library directors are vitally
Interested in the expansion of library facilities and
will be able to examine the many facets of the Homewood library in detail.
After touring the library, the librarians will hear
a discussion on the application of computers. Some
computer techniques are now in operation in libraries
and the new Hopkins library will try to use computers
in all areas of book circulation.
Tonight Dr. Milton Eisenhower will address a dinner of the library guests at the Sheraton Belvedere
and tomorrow tours will allow a detailed inspection
of the six story structure.
At lunch tomorrow the group will hear the comments of the Hopkins' Operation Research group.
Dean Robert H. Roy, Drs. Gore, Cartwright, and
Mullick, head librarian Berthel and assistant librarian
Walton will participate in the discussion. This group
under the direction of Dean Roy has been conducting
the survey on the use of computers.

Dr. Frederick Moore should stand as example and
inspiration to this community so often plagued with
the "malady of the quotidian." Who is Dr. Moore, that
we should so commend him? Go, men, to the place where
he is enshrined. Go to the ante room outside the meeting
place of our board of trustees, and there, in Shriver
Hall, take down an impression of the man whose
memorial rests so near to the councils of greatness.
Perhaps it will also help you to understand that
the board of trustees is totally unaware of the existence
of any Dr. Frederick Moore, and that there is no record
of his having ever been associated with the university.
He was created: given birth in the fertile mind of a
felicitous individual. He is the supreme fiction in a
world of unimaginable reality.

A Compatible Conclusion
We.should have realized that any time one sticks
one's neck out, one takes the chance of getting "I told
you so" from parties who certainly never did. The
confusion of Phi Gam as to the meaning of their own
constitution prevented them from being right as well as
righteous from the start. Their recent enlightenment,
however, and the private admission of the Phi Gam
president that he had previously misunderstood the
"compatibility" clause, leaves thy Gams without the need
to defend their discriminatory clause on the grounds
of "private organiaztion." We can only admit that the
issue has been rationalized out of existence.
It is time to make a mature and responsible conclusion to our discussion of the issue, and this will be
best done by ignoring the petty vindictiveness of dealing with issues through personalities. The News-Letter,
and not one individual with access to this platform,
brought the discrimination issue to light, sought its
clarification, and is now willing to admit that others
have borne it back to obscurity.
The student body has approved the right of a private organization to function according to its own desires,
and with attitudes opposing those of the community.
The student body has not approved of discrimination:
the Student Council, indeed has urged its elimination.
Surely some good has been the result of our refusal to
mirror the apathy and complacency that surround us.
Surely we have been both "gadfly and scape-goat."

Homewood House
The new library and the newly constructed gate
on Charles Street have combined to accent the beauty,
simplicity, and grace of Homewood House. With two
new additions to the east side of the campus, it is time
to take a fresh look at that building.
From Charles Street, the Homewood House seems
to possess all the grace and charm lacking in its new
neighbors. Closer inspection confirms this initial impression. The coordination of vertical and horizontal
planes blended with gentle curves becomes even more
apparent.
Unfortunately, something else also becomes apparent in a close inspection of Homewood House. The
exterior is in obvious need of repair. The panels above
the windows and the window sills are flaking.
The center steps on the south side are badly
chipped. The graceful railing on these steps, the original
entrance to the house, is overgrown with vines.
Nor is everything perfect within. Large areas of
chipped and flaked paint can be seen on the stairway
leading to the attic. The present condition of the house
calls for both repair and thoughts of restoration.
Homewood House, as the model for all campus
architecture and as a sign of excellence, is a logical
place for the office of the President. But it must he
remembered that the building is a treasure, and as such,
should not be forced to house as many offices as people
can cram into it. The nineteenth century beauty of the
house is hidden in many places by file cabinets, modern
desks, and secretaries. New space will soon be available
in a renovated Gilman Hall and a new classroom building.
Before the Second World War, Homewood House
was a representation of nineteenth century design, inside and out. Much of the antique furniture used in the
house is available in Evergreen House or in Dr. Eisenhower's home. The plant manager, the university curator, and Dr. Eisenhower himself, might consider restoring Homewood House to the monument of good
taste it used to be. As such, it would be a appropriate
setting for the office of the President of a great
university.

By DAVID ABRAHAMSON
(Editor's note: Recently freshmen were asked

was written by David Abrahamson, a resident of

Hop: Colloquialism no longer in vogue used to
Identify a type of local orgy whose participants
were limited to particular educational as well as
social in-groups; Etmology—lost in the far reaches
of the Great Americana; suspected to have its
origins in a form of ineffective fertility rite.
The very first morning after I had put up with
the dust, noise, bedding and ventilation of the
Alumni Memorial Residences, an enterprising
upperclassman approached me and inquired,
"Well, boy, what do you think of the Hop?" My
first thought was that I was being propositioned,
and that I should return at once to the dust,
noise, bedding, and ventilation of my room to
reassess my values.
But then, after seeing his belt garnished on one

side with a K&E masterpiece plus case and on
the other with a clipboard, and after noticing the
four inches of glassware on either side of his nose,
I realized that he must be One of the Fellows.
You know, the ones Dad always used to reminisce
about. I can still hear his voice now, like a
majestic bull moose wallowing in the tarpits of
the Great Northwest, uttering, "Why son, some
of the greatest memories you will ever have will
be of those times when you are out Carousing
with the Fellows!"
This was one of the fellows. I smiled. "The
Hop? I haven't seen it yet. Is that what you do
around here?" He smiled. I started reassessing.
Since this time, myself and most of the four
hundred and twenty-eight others have learned.
Unfortunately, some have not.
And what of those others? Their fate? To fill
the honored rolls of the Fellows of the Hop. And
they shall bear sons college-bound. And they will
have sweet memories.

Dr. John Coleman Bennett, President and Reinhold

Pigskin Hop
The annual Pigskin Hop will be held this year on Saturday evening, November 21, at the Oregon Ridge Ski Lodge.
Sponsored by the H Club, the dance is being held to obtain
funds for the purchasing of blankets and other tokens as
awards of recognition for men who participate on Hopkins
teams three years in a row.
The lodge was chosen as the site of the dance because
of the attractive setting and intimate atmosphere it will
afford. It is located on Beaverdam Road, just off the York
Road expressway.
Music will be provided by a local band, the Lafayettes,
and set-ups will be available but not provided. Sport jacket
and tie is the dress for the occasion.
This year, only two hundred tickets will be sold, in order
to preserve the cordiality of the setting. Tickets sell for five
dollars apiece, and may be obtained in the basement of
Levering Hall.

Class Day
In the traditional Fall anti-apathy campaign, Class Day
ranks high at the Hop. Friday, Nov. 20, at 1 p.m. classes
will be suspended to facilitate the annual struggle between
the freshman, sophomore, junior, and senior classes.
Students are expected to compete vigorously for their
classes in such events as ping pong, touch football, and
assorted novelty races. For those who feel they can best aid
their class effort through mental endeavor, there will be
bridge, chess, and possibly debate competitions. In any event
healthy class struggle is a sure counter to the lethargic
mildew mid-terms impose upon us all.

Homewood House
The new library and the newly constructed gate
on Charles Street have combined to accent the beauty,
simplicity, and grace of Homewood House. With two
new additions to the east side of the campus, it is time
to take a fresh look at that building.
From Charles Street, the Homewood House seems
to possess all the grace and charm lacking in its new
neighbors. Closer inspection confirms this initial impression. The coordination of vertical and horizontal
planes blended with gentle curves becomes even more
apparent.
Unfortunately, something else also becomes apparent in a close inspection of Homewood House. The
exterior is in obvious need of repair. The panels above
the windows and the window sills are flaking.
The center steps on the south side are badly
chipped. The graceful railing on these steps, the original
entrance to the house, is overgrown with vines.

house is hidden in many places by file cabinets, modern
desks, and secretaries. New space will soon be available
in a renovated Gilman Hall and a new classroom building.

was a representation of nineteenth century design, inside and out. Much of the antique furniture used in the
